In the Bodhisattva Ground section of the Basic Section, the first part of the chapter on morality, the tenth of the first fifteen chapters, what is the perfection of morality of bodhisattvas?
The uddÄna says:
The essence, all difficulties, all approaches, good people,
All kinds, fulfilling wishes, happiness in both this and future lives, and purity.ğŸ”½These nine characteristics
Are called morality in brief.

First, the essence of morality.

What is the essence of morality of bodhisattvas?
It is said that in brief, it has four merits.
One should know that this is called the bodhisattva's intrinsic morality.
What are the four?
First, correct acceptance from others.
Second, pure wholesome intention.
Third, being purified after transgression.
Fourth, deeply respecting and being mindful without transgression.
Because bodhisattvas correctly accept from others,
if there is any transgression against the precepts they are learning,
they immediately look externally at others and deeply feel shame.
Because bodhisattvas have pure wholesome intention,
if there is any transgression against the precepts they are learning,
they immediately look internally at themselves and deeply feel shame.
Because bodhisattvas, after transgressing the precepts they are learning,
deeply respect and are mindful without initial transgression,
for these two causes and conditions,
they are free from all regrets.
In this way, bodhisattvas, with correct acceptance from others and pure wholesome intention,
take shame and conscience as their basis and give rise to them.ğŸ”½Because of shame and conscience, they are able to well protect the precepts they have received.
Because they well protect the precepts they have received, they are free from all regrets.
Moreover, within this,
one receives it correctly from others.
With a pure and wholesome intention.
These two are the Dharma.
Having transgressed, one returns to purity.
Deeply respectful and mindful, without transgression.
These two are drawn by the previous two Dharmas.
Moreover, within this,
one receives it correctly from others.
With a pure and wholesome intention.
Deeply respectful and mindful, without transgression.
By means of these three Dharmas, one should know that one is able to not violate the pure precepts received by the bodhisattva.
Having transgressed, one returns to purity.
By means of this one Dharma, one should know that one is able to return to purity after transgression.
Thus, the bodhisattva's moral discipline of four meritorious qualities by nature,
one should know, is precisely the excellent pure precepts.
Correctly receiving and following the training,
one is able to benefit oneself and others.
Benefiting and bringing peace to innumerable beings,
having compassion for the world, gods and humans, etc.,
in order to cause them to obtain benefit, benefit, and peace and happiness,
one should know, is precisely the immeasurable pure precepts.
Because it includes the training of innumerable bodhisattvas.
One should know that it is the pure precepts that benefit all sentient beings.
Because it can presently benefit and bring peace to all sentient beings.
One should know that it is the pure precepts that attain great fruits and benefits.
Because it includes and bestows the fruit of unsurpassed perfect enlightenment.
This is called the intrinsic nature of the bodhisattva's precepts.
What are the bodhisattva's all-inclusive precepts?
It is said that the bodhisattva's precepts are of two kinds.
One is the precepts for the householder stage,
and the other is the precepts for the renunciant stage. These are called all-inclusive precepts.
Moreover, based on these two kinds of pure precepts for householders and renunciants,
they are summarized into three kinds.ğŸ”½First, the precepts of restraining from wrongdoing,
second, the precepts of embracing wholesome dharmas,
and third, the precepts of benefiting sentient beings.
As for the precepts of restraining from wrongdoing,
they refer to the precepts of the seven assemblies of individual liberation accepted by bodhisattvas.ğŸ”½They are the precepts for fully ordained monks,ğŸ”½the precepts for fully ordained nuns,
and the precepts for probationary nuns.
The precepts for male novices.
The precepts for female novices.ğŸ”½The precepts for male lay followers.
The precepts for female lay followers.
These seven kinds.
Depend on the two groups of lay and ordained people.
As appropriate, one should know.
This is called the bodhisattva's moral discipline.
The moral discipline of embracing wholesome dharmas.
It means that after the bodhisattvas have received the moral discipline,
All for the sake of great enlightenment.
By body, speech, and mind, accumulating all wholesome dharmas.
In general, it is called the moral discipline of embracing wholesome dharmas.
What is this again?
It means that the bodhisattvas depend on the precepts and abide by the precepts.
In listening, in contemplation, in cultivating stillness and insight, in enjoying solitude,
They diligently study and practice.
In this way, from time to time, towards the elders,
They diligently cultivate the practices of joining palms, rising to greet, inquiring about well-being, bowing, and paying respect.
Right then, towards the elders, they diligently serve and respect them.
Towards those who are sick, they compassionately and earnestly attend to and provide for them.
To all wonderful teachings, one offers praise.
To those individuals with merit,
one sincerely praises them.
In the ten directions, to all sentient beings and all meritorious actions,
with the supreme intention, one gives rise to pure faith and expresses joy.
Regarding all transgressions committed by others, one patiently accepts them.
Regarding all roots of goodness created by body, speech, and mind,
one dedicates them to unsurpassed perfect enlightenment.
From time to time, one gives rise to various correct vows and with all kinds of supreme offerings, one makes offerings to the Buddha, Dharma, and Sangha.
Regarding all wholesome practices, one is always diligent and energetic in cultivation.
Regarding body, speech, and mind, one abides in non-negligence.
Regarding all precepts, one is mindful, aware, and practices correctly.
One guards and protects the sense-doors.
Regarding food, one knows moderation.
In the first and last watches of the night, one always practices vigilance.
One draws near to good people and relies on good friends.
Regarding one's own faults, one clearly understands and deeply sees their shortcomings.
Having thoroughly understood and deeply seen the faults,
those who have not yet violated [the precepts] should focus their minds on protecting and upholding them.
Those who have already violated [the precepts] should, in the presence of the Buddhas, Bodhisattvas, and those who share the same Dharma,
sincerely confess and repent in accordance with the Dharma.
Such types of precepts that attract and uphold,
and cause the increase and growth of wholesome dharmas,
are called the bodhisattva precepts for embracing wholesome dharmas.
What are the bodhisattva precepts for benefiting sentient beings?
It should be known that these precepts are summarized into eleven aspects.
What are the eleven?
It means that the bodhisattvas are able to benefit sentient beings,
and assist them in various activities.
Regarding the various sufferings that arise in sentient beings, such as illness,
they also assist in caring for the sick.
Moreover, the bodhisattvas, based on various mundane and supramundane benefits,
are able to expound the essential teachings for sentient beings.
First, they skillfully explain, then they explain in accordance with reason,
and finally they enable them to attain various benefits.
Moreover, bodhisattvas are good at repaying kindness to sentient beings who have previously shown them kindness.
In accordance with their needs, they manifest to repay their kindness.
Moreover, bodhisattvas are able to rescue and protect sentient beings who have fallen into various fears such as lions, tigers, wolves, ghosts, spirits, kings, thieves, water, and fire.
Causing them to be free from these various fearful situations.
Moreover, bodhisattvas are good at comforting sentient beings who have lost their wealth, treasures, and relatives.
Causing them to be free from sorrow and worry.
Moreover, bodhisattvas provide all the necessities to sentient beings who lack the requisites for life.
Moreover, bodhisattvas follow the principles of reason.
Correctly providing support and properly leading the assembly.
Moreover, bodhisattvas follow worldly customs.
Business affairs and conversation.
Calling out, going and coming.
Discussing and consoling.
Going to meet others in a timely manner.
Receiving and accepting food and drink from others.
To summarize,
They are far removed from all unwholesome and disagreeable conduct.
Their minds are all in accord with the remaining matters.
Moreover, if bodhisattvas, whether in secret or openly,
Reveal their true virtues,
They cause sentient beings to joyfully progress in their studies.
Moreover, with regard to those who have transgressions,
Bodhisattvas inwardly harbor thoughts of intimacy, benefit, and comfort, and with an attitude of superiority, they subdue, scold, punish, and expel them.
This is in order to cause them to leave unwholesome states and be placed in wholesome states.ğŸ”½Moreover, by means of the power of spiritual penetrations,
Bodhisattvas skillfully manifest the characteristics of the various destinies such as the hells.
They cause sentient beings to become disgusted with unwholesomeness.
Skillfully guiding them to enter the Buddha's holy teachings, they give rise to joy and faith, arouse a sense of the rare and extraordinary, and diligently cultivate correct practices.
How do bodhisattvas abide in the precepts of the code of conduct?
How do they abide in the precepts of embracing wholesome dharmas?
How do they abide in the precepts of benefiting sentient beings?
How do they well protect the precepts of the code of conduct?
It is the well-cultivated precepts of gathering wholesome dharmas and the well-practiced precepts of benefiting sentient beings in all ways.
It means that when bodhisattvas abide in the precepts of the discipline of individual liberation,
they abandon the position of a wheel-turning king and go forth from home to homelessness.
They do not care about the position of a wheel-turning king as if discarding filthy grass.
It is like a poor person who, in order to make a living,
abandons inferior desires and goes forth from home to homelessness, not caring about inferior desires.

It is not like how a bodhisattva with a pure intention abandons the position of a wheel-turning king and goes forth from home to homelessness, not caring about the position of a wheel-turning king, the most excellent among humans.
Moreover, bodhisattvas abide in the precepts of discipline.
In the future, in the palace of the demon king of the heavens, they do not give rise to joy and delight in the wonderful desires there.
They also do not aspire to or seek out those wonderful desires, practicing pure conduct.
They still contemplate those wonderful desires as if they were entering a vast and varied forest of terror.
How much more so for the other desires!
Moreover, after bodhisattvas have gone forth from home to homelessness,
In the present world, they are honored by sentient beings and receive various kinds of excellent offerings and respect.
With right wisdom, they carefully contemplate
and still do not savor them, much less those inferior offerings and respect from other inferior sentient beings.
Moreover, bodhisattvas always delight in solitude, whether in a quiet place by themselves
or in the midst of a crowd.
At all times, their minds are focused on solitude and they abide in tranquility.
They are not content merely with the discipline and precepts.
Relying on the precepts and abiding in the precepts, they diligently cultivate the immeasurable samÄdhis of bodhisattvas,
in order to attain mastery in their realization.
Moreover, even though bodhisattvas are in a mixed crowd,
they do not delight in even the slightest improper conversation.
Dwelling in solitude,
they do not give rise to even the slightest evil thoughts.
If at times they forget and temporarily give rise to [evil thoughts],ğŸ”½they immediately give rise to intense remorse and shame.
Deeply seeing their faults, they repeatedly repent and feel ashamed.
Because they deeply see their faults, even if they temporarily give rise to improper speech or evil thoughts,
they are able to quickly and peacefully abide in right mindfulness.
Regarding them, they attain a mind that never does them again.
By this cause and condition, they are then able to restrain themselves.
Because of being accustomed to restraint, they are gradually able to, as in the past,
deeply give rise to joy and delight in their present practice.
Now, they peacefully abide in their non-practice.
Joy and delight are also like this.
They are also able to go against and prevent their non-arising.
Moreover, all bodhisattvas, regarding all the precepts of the bodhisattvas,
and having heard the vast, immeasurable, inconceivable, long-lasting, and extremely difficult practices of the bodhisattvas who have entered the great stages,
their minds are without fear and also without cowardice.
They only think like this:
They are also human beings.
Gradually cultivating and learning in all the bodhisattva precepts, which are vast, immeasurable, inconceivable, and of pure body, speech, and so forth,
they accomplish and perfect them.
I am also a human being.
Gradually cultivating and learning, there is definitely no doubt.
One will certainly attain the pure bodily and verbal precepts, and so forth, and accomplish and perfect them.
Moreover, all bodhisattvas abiding in the precepts of discipline always examine their own faults and do not seek the faults of others.
Universally, with regard to all violent and precept-breaking sentient beings,
they have no harmful mind and no angry mind.
Because bodhisattvas, due to harboring the highest Dharma and great compassion towards them,
in the present give rise to a deeply compassionate mind and a mind wishing to benefit.
Moreover, all bodhisattvas abiding in the precepts of discipline,
even though they may encounter others using their hands, feet, clods of earth, stones, swords, sticks, and so forth to inflict harm,
they still have not the slightest angry or resentful mind.ğŸ”½How much less would they wish to speak evil words or do harm to them?
How much less would they speak words of slander and rebuke?
Using a small amount of painful contact to do harm.
Moreover, all bodhisattvas abiding in the precepts of discipline,
fully accomplish the five branches that encompass the practice of heedfulness.
First, the practice of heedfulness that accompanies the past.
Second, the practice of heedfulness that accompanies the future.
Third, the practice of heedfulness that accompanies the present.
Fourth, the practice of heedfulness that was previously done.
Fifth, the practice of heedfulness that accompanies the present moment.
That is to say, when bodhisattvas are correctly cultivating and practicing bodhisattva learning,
if they repent in accordance with the Dharma for past transgressions that they have already committed,
this is called the bodhisattvas' practice of heedfulness that accompanies the past.
If they repent in accordance with the Dharma for future transgressions that they have not yet committed,
this is called the bodhisattvas' practice of heedfulness that accompanies the future.
If they repent in accordance with the Dharma for present transgressions that they are committing,
this is called the bodhisattvas' practice of heedfulness that accompanies the present.
If bodhisattvas arouse intense self-directed resolve regarding future transgressions that they will commit at a later time, thinking, I will definitely act in such and such a way as is appropriate,
and abide in such and such a way as is appropriate.
I will act in this way,
Abiding in this way,
without committing any offenses,
this is called the bodhisattva's practice of heedfulness beforehand.
If the bodhisattvas rely on this very practice of heedfulness beforehand,
as they should practice,
as they should abide,
they practice in this way,
they abide in this way,
without giving rise to offenses,
this is called the bodhisattva's practice of heedfulness that accompanies [good conduct] at the same time.
Moreover, the bodhisattvas abide in the precepts of the code of conduct.
They conceal their own good deeds and reveal their own faults.
They have few desires, are content, and can endure various sufferings.
Their nature is free from worry and anxiety, not agitated or restless, and their deportment is tranquil.
They are free from hypocrisy and all other dharmas that give rise to wrong livelihood.
The bodhisattvas accomplish these ten aspects.
They are called those who abide in the precepts of the code of conduct and skillfully guard the precepts of the code of conduct.ğŸ”½Namely, they do not long for past desires,
and they do not seek future desires,

Moreover, they delight in being far away from [desire] and do not give rise to satisfaction.
Moreover, they are able to sweep away improper speech and evil thoughts.
Moreover, they are able to not belittle themselves.
Moreover, their nature is gentle.
Moreover, they are able to endure.
Moreover, they are not negligent.
Moreover, they are able to possess the pure livelihood of precepts.
Moreover, the bodhisattvas who have already been able to abide in the precepts of embracing wholesome dharmas,
if they give rise to even a little attachment to their bodies and wealth,
they will not tolerate it.
How much less so if it is much [attachment]?
Moreover, they also do not tolerate even a little of the fundamental afflictions and secondary afflictions such as anger and resentment that are the causes and conditions for violating the precepts.
Moreover, they also do not tolerate the mind of hatred, harm, and resentment that arises towards others.
Moreover, they also do not tolerate the laziness and indolence that arise.
Moreover, they also do not tolerate the attachment to the taste of meditative absorption and the afflictions that arise from meditative absorption.
Moreover, they truly understand five things.
Namely, they truly understand the benefits of good results.
Moreover, they are able to truly understand the causes of goodness.
Moreover, they are able to truly understand the right and wrong of the causes and results of goodness.
Moreover, they truly understand the obstacles to embracing the good Dharma.
These bodhisattvas see the great benefits in good results and seek the causes of goodness.
In order to embrace the good, they truly understand the right and wrong.
Because of this, the bodhisattvas attain good results.
They do not falsely see permanence in impermanence.
They do not falsely see happiness in suffering.
They do not falsely see purity in impurity.
They do not falsely see self in non-self.
They truly understand the obstacles to embracing the good Dharma.
In order to embrace the good, they quickly distance themselves from them.
Because of these ten aspects,
the bodhisattvas are said to abide in the precepts of embracing the good Dharma.
They are able to quickly embrace all aspects of the good,
Namely, the sequence of giving,
the sequence of precepts,
If it is gradual forbearance,
if it is gradual effort, if it is gradual meditation, and if it is the five kinds of wisdom.
Moreover, the bodhisattvas, by means of eleven aspects,
are called those who abide in the precepts that benefit all kinds of sentient beings.
In each aspect, all kinds are accomplished. It means that the bodhisattvas, in the various activities of sentient beings,
all become their companions.
That is to say, in the activities of thought and action,
and in the activities of effort and action, they are all able to be their companions, either on the road going or coming,
or in the correct practice of activities,
or in guarding their possessions,
or in reconciling those who are estranged,
or in gatherings for the sake of merit,
they all become their companions.

That is to say, for sentient beings who encounter epidemics,
they attend to and provide for them.ğŸ”½For the blind, they guide them.
For the deaf, they convey the meaning.
Those with speech impediments are taught through visualization.
Those who are confused about directions and paths are shown how to encounter the road.
Those who lack limbs are given assistance in carrying their burdens.
The foolish are instructed in superior wisdom.

They are enlightened and liberated from the suffering of the afflictions of desire and greed.
In this way, if they suffer from the afflictions of anger, dullness,
Sloth, restlessness,ğŸ”½and doubt,
For sentient beings who suffer from the afflictions of doubt and so forth,
They are enlightened and liberated from the suffering of the afflictions of doubt and so forth.

They are enlightened and liberated from the suffering of discursive thoughts of desire.

Discursive thoughts associated with anger, harm, relatives, country, immortality, contempt, and family lineage should be understood in the same way.
For sentient beings who suffer from being despised and defeated by others,
They are enlightened and liberated from the suffering of being despised and defeated.
For sentient beings who suffer from fatigue on the road,
They offer seats, places, adjust the body, and massage,
Causing them to rest and relieve the various sufferings of fatigue.
Moreover, the bodhisattvas expound the Dharma for sentient beings in accordance with the truth.
That is to say, for sentient beings who delight in engaging in evil conduct,
in order to cause them to abandon all evil conduct,
they use appropriate words, companions, and methods that are in accord with the Dharma.
They are clear, useful, appropriate, and in accord with the Dharma.
They expound the Dharma of the provisions for constant and diligent practice.
Or they skillfully expound the Dharma.
Just as for sentient beings who delight in engaging in evil conduct, in order to cause them to abandon all evil conduct,
so too for sentient beings who engage in stingy conduct,
in order to cause them to abandon stingy conduct,
for those who seek wealth and treasures in the present life,
in order to cause them to gather much wealth and treasure with little effort and to guard it without loss,
for those who harbor hatred and jealousy towards the Buddha's holy teachings,
in order to cause them to attain pure faith and realize the pure view,
to transcend all evil destinies and exhaust all bonds,
to transcend all suffering,
one should know it is the same.
with regard to those sentient beings who have been kind to them,
deeply know their kindness and always think of repaying them.
Upon briefly seeing them, they express respect and say, Welcome.
With a cheerful face, they comfort them.
They speak sincerely and pleasantly, arranging seats and banquets for them to sit.
They repay them with wealth and offerings that are equal to or greater than [the kindness received],
not with inferior [things].
Even though they do not request help with their work,
they should still assist [them].

with regard to skillful means,
with regard to rescuing from fear,
with regard to resolving sorrow in the face of misfortune and distress,ğŸ”½with regard to providing resources,

with regard to following the mind, and with regard to revealing true virtues to bring deep joy,
with regard to taming with affectionate love,
with regard to attracting through the display of spiritual powers,
it should be known that the extensive explanation is the same as this.
Moreover, bodhisattvas are able to rescue and protect those sentient beings who are in fear.
This refers to various fears from animals, water, fire,
kings, thieves, and enemies,
masters of the household, officials,
fear of not being able to make a living, fear of a bad reputation,
fear of the awesome spiritual power of the great assembly,
fear of non-human beings, corpses, and goblins, etc. - all of these they are able to rescue and protect, enabling them to attain peace and security.
Moreover, bodhisattvas are able to skillfully console and liberate those sentient beings who are in decline and distress, enabling them to be free from sorrow and worry.
This may be based on the loss of relatives, namely parents, siblings,
wife, children, slaves,ğŸ”½servants, clan elders,
friends, relatives, teachers,
masters, and others who are respected.

Skillfully consoling and liberating them, enabling them to be free from sorrow and distress.
Or it may be based on the loss of wealth and treasures,
namely being robbed by kings or thieves,
burned by fire, drowned by water,
or deceived by fraud.

Or for the sake of evil relatives, one is wrongly taken by force.
Or the family gives rise to fire and is consumed.
In these and other ways, wealth and treasures are lost.
The bodhisattva skillfully explains and resolves them, causing one to be free from sorrow and distress.
Due to these causes and conditions, all sentient beings give rise to three levels of sorrow, upper, middle, and lower.
The bodhisattva is able to correctly explain and resolve them.
Moreover, the bodhisattvas are equipped with the necessities of life.
According to those who come seeking, they immediately give them.

If they seek garlands and ointments,
they give them garlands and ointments.
If they seek a place to rest, they give them a place to rest.
If they seek various kinds of light, they give them light.
Moreover, the bodhisattvas by nature delight in accepting all sentient beings.
In accordance with the Dharma, they lead the assembly and skillfully benefit them.
First, with an undefiled mind, one gives them a place to stay.
With a compassionate mind, one manifests benefiting them.
Then, one gives them Dharma robes, food and drink, bedding, medicine for illness, and necessities for the body according to the Dharma.
If one does not have them oneself, one should seek and give them from faithful elders, laypeople, and Brahmins.

One shares with the assembly the Dharma robes, food and drink, bedding and seats, and medicine for illness and necessities for the body that one has obtained according to the Dharma. One does not keep them hidden.
From time to time, one properly instructs them with the eight kinds of instructions.
One properly admonishes them with the five kinds of admonitions.
Here, the instructions and admonitions that are spoken of.

Moreover, the minds of sentient beings are by nature fond of following along.
When following along with the mind, one first knows the essence and nature of sentient beings.
Knowing the essence and nature,
one follows along with sentient beings in the way they should dwell together.
One should then live together with them in this way.
According to the beings to be trained, one should practice together with them in this way.
If bodhisattvas wish to follow the minds of beings to be trained,
they should carefully contemplate.
If in this way or that way, engaging in bodily and verbal actions
would give rise to others' sorrow and suffering,
and if that sorrow and suffering would not cause them to leave unwholesome states and establish them in wholesome states,
then at that time the bodhisattva, in regard to such matters, engaging in bodily and verbal actions,

In this way, sorrow and suffering, if able to cause them to leave unwholesome states and establish them in wholesome states,
then at that time the bodhisattva, in regard to such matters, engaging in bodily and verbal actions, abiding in a compassionate mind,
does not follow the minds of such beings.
Skillfully contemplating, making an effort to encourage them, he must cause them to appear.

If oneâ€™s physical and verbal actions cause other sentient beings to experience mental pain and suffering,
and if this mental pain and suffering does not cause others or other sentient beings or both to leave the state of nonvirtue and be established in the state of virtue,
then at that time a bodhisattva, in regard to such a matter, engages in physical and verbal actions.
In order to protect the minds of others, he or she examines them with skill and deliberately restrains them with effort,

If this mental pain and suffering causes others or other sentient beings or both to leave the state of nonvirtue and be established in the state of virtue,
then at that time a bodhisattva, in regard to such a matter, engages in physical and verbal actions.
Dwelling in a compassionate mind,
he or she does not follow the minds of such sentient beings.
With skill, he or she examines them and deliberately encourages them with effort, causing them to be carried out.
He or she also examines them again.
If, in regard to such a matter, a bodhisattvaâ€™s physical and verbal actions cause others to experience mental pain and suffering,
then these two kinds of actions,
are not included in the precepts of a bodhisattva.
It is not conducive to the accumulations of merit and wisdom.
Such sorrow and suffering cannot cause others to leave unwholesome states and establish them in wholesome states.
At that time, the bodhisattva engages in physical and verbal actions.
In order to protect the minds of others, he skillfully examines and energetically restrains them, preventing them from manifesting.
The opposite of this is engaging in physical and verbal actions, which should be understood as before.
As with giving rise to sorrow and suffering,
it should be understood in the same way when giving rise to joy and pleasure, as appropriate.
Moreover, the bodhisattva who accords with the minds of others,
knows that other sentient beings are bound by the fetters of anger and that the fetters of anger are difficult to abandon in the present moment.
He does not even praise them,
let alone disparage them.
At that time, he does not even admonish them.
Moreover, the bodhisattva who accords with the minds of others,
even if others do not come to discuss and console him,
he should still go himself to discuss and console them.
How much more so if they come, but he does not reciprocate.
Moreover, the bodhisattva who accords with the minds of others,
They will never intentionally annoy or offend others.
Except for reprimanding those who commit offenses.
With a compassionate mind and tranquil faculties,
They reprimand as appropriate to subdue them.
Moreover, bodhisattvas who accord with the minds of others
Will never ridicule or belittle others, causing them to feel ashamed.
They do not make others feel uneasy.
They also do not cause others to feel sorrowful and regretful.
Although they can subdue and defeat others,
They do not expose others' faults.
Although others may have pure faith,
They are humble and never show off to be self-important.
Moreover, bodhisattvas who accord with the minds of others
Do not associate too closely with sentient beings, nor do they not associate with them at all.
